title.narrative: Microenterprise Opportunities for People with Disabilities

description.narrative: 1) Inclusive MED training curriculum for Trickle Upâ€™s partner agencies, covering strategies for outreach to people with disabilities, awareness raising and sensitivity training, best practices for program implementation related to different forms of disability, and other key topics; 2) Training workshop and ongoing technical assistance to support first-time implementation of the Trickle Up program by ADISA, a DPO; 3) Inclusion workshops for 4 current non-DPO partners (a total of 10 days of training per partner), each reaching between 18,000 and 70,000 beneficiaries per year; 4) Through implementation of Trickle Up by ADISA, sustainable livelihoods for 200 people with disabilities (at least 75% women) benefiting 1,000 people (est. 5 household members/microenterprise) with measurable outcomes including increased food security; 5) Through implementation of Trickle Up by non-DPOs, sustainable livelihoods for 120 people with disabilities (at least 75% women) benefiting 600 people; 6) Capacity building for Trickle Up HQ staff and 3 regional offices through a best practices paper analyzing learning from our disability projects in Mali and Guatemala; 7) Dissemination of best practices to the broader field through at least two practitioner workshops. One workshop will be held in the US through InterAction or The Small Enterprise Education and Promotion (SEEP) Network, a leading international network that connects microenterprise and microfinance practitioners from around the world todevelop practical guidance and tools, build capacity, and help set standards to advance the common vision of a sustainable income in every household. The other workshop will be held in Guatemala City for NGOs, INGOs and DPOs active in-country; and 8) Circulation of best practices paper at the annual conference of 10 leading microfinance/MED organizations that, with Trickle Up, are participating in a global project led by CGAP to identify replicable methodologies for serving the poorest.
People with disabilities living in extreme poverty

The goals of the project are to 1) increase outreach to and inclusion of people with disabilities in microenterprise development programs, 2) reduce extreme poverty among 320 participants with disabilities, with a focus on women, and 3) promote greater inclusion of people with disabilities across Trickle Up regional programs and in other microenterprise development and microfinance programs. The project involves training a disabled persons organization (DPO) to provide microenterprise development support, to form savings groups with the participants, and to provide grants to capitalize and catalyze their productive activities. The second stage of the program involves training non-DPO local NGOs to incorporate people with disabilities into their microenterprise development programs. The project will culminate in the sharing of best practices related to inclusive microenterprise development to be shared with practitioners in both Guatemala and the United States.
